units.name: Biovore
units.description: Artillery unit that creates Spore Mines which explode on contact with the enemy.
units.flavour: A Biovore is a squat, bloated creature—yet no less deadly for all that. Deep within its lumpen form, the Biovore nurtures a clutch of Spore Mines—living bombs that blanket the enemy in acids, poisons and shrapnel-sized pieces of chitin. Biovores thump forward in battle, bony protrusions on their fore-limbs anchoring themselves into the ground as they release their vile payload in a single shuddering spasm.

units.name: Doom
units.flavour: The Doom appears to be a one-off creation of the Hive Mind, produced with great difficulty. It is a unique vampiric Zoanthrope, that feeds upon psychic energy. Over its skull sits a long, spine-like growth like a hood and vestigial claws emerge like ribs from its side. Psychic energy can be visibly seen crackling along these structures. In combat, it uses them to focus its psychic powers and draw all the life-energy from its surroundings. A similar creature is thought to have singlehandedly destroyed the Aeldari Craftworld of Malan'tai by devouring the spirits from its Infinity Circuits.

units.name: Carnifex
units.description: Monstrous creature unit with devastating close combat capabilities.
units.flavour: Carnifexes are living engines of destruction, towering monsters of unyielding armoured chitin and knotted alien musculature. They are one of the toughest and deadliest of all a hive fleet's warrior creatures, created to spearhead assaults in massed battles. Though the Hive Mind has since created larger warrior-organisms, few are the Carnifex's equal in terms of size to strength, nor in terms of sheer destructive potential.

units.name: Exocrine
units.description: Monstrous creature unit that excels when stationary.
units.flavour: Exocrines are feared for their ability to deal death from afar. The most distinctive feature of an Exocrine is its dorsal bio-cannon, which emits a high-pitched hiss a second before firing, giving its prey just enough time to realise the danger they are in before searing plasma scours them into atoms.

units.name: Gargoyle
units.description: Jump infantry unit.
units.flavour: A Tyranid attack is preceded by the beating of thousands of membranous wings as Gargoyle broods descend upon the foe, blotting out the sun and spitting death from their fleshborers. Their winged manoeuvrability gives Gargoyles a distinct hunting advantage. Wherever Tyranids attack a planet, the defenders look fearfully to the skies, for they know that every sky-borne shadow could be a flock of Gargoyles about to attack.

units.name: Haruspex
units.description: Monstrous creature unit with a grasping tongue.
units.flavour: The Tyranid Haruspex is a ferocious beast created to consume biomass at a sickening pace. It is possessed of a rapacious appetite, driven by the need to sate an infinite hunger. Few foes are foolish enough to stand before a feeding Haruspex, for it can devour an entire platoon of soldiers in a matter of moments, shovelling victim after victim into its craw without ever slowing down. Any morsel that proves too large to be swallowed in one gulp is seized with the Haruspex's gargantuan claws and ripped, crushed or battered apart with negligent ease.

units.name: Headquarters
units.description: Headquarters unit that represents a city's defenses.
units.flavour: The organising organism of a Tyranid's hive, the Norn Cyst is always the first biostructure to be placed. The Malanthrope places the hive in a suitable location and tends its exponential growth as the hive manages and defends any connected biostructures. When the hive's use has passed, the Malanthrope strips the Cyst's living connections and carries to a new source of biomass. The remaining redundant structure sloughs itself back into the nearest reclamation pool. Soon, the hive is completely gone.

units.name: HiveCrone
units.description: Flyer unit that excels against airborne targets.
units.flavour: The Hive Crone is a flying monstrosity used by the Tyranids to establish air superiority over prey worlds. It is a creature perfectly adapted to aerial combat, able to wrestle enemy aircraft out of the skies as proficiently as any daredevil pilot at the controls of a sophisticated jet-fighter.

units.name: HiveTyrant
units.description: Flying synapse hero unit with terrifying psychic powers.
units.flavour: Hive Tyrants are the commanders of the Tyranid swarms and enact the Hive Mind's will on the field of battle. Though individuals display a wide variety of physical characteristics, all Hive Tyrants are fearsome hulking monsters that tower over even a Dreadnought. They are brutally strong, able to shatter ferrocrete with sickening ease. Every part of such a beast's body is perfectly created to kill, even the layers of chitinous plating that protect them. A Hive Tyrant is a formidable opponent at any distance, as deadly with ranged weapons as it is with bonesword or claw.

units.name: Hormagaunt
units.description: Basic close combat infantry unit.
units.flavour: Hormagaunts are vicious and extraordinarily single-minded predators that will pursue their victims without pause or respite. With powerful hind legs, Hormagaunts dart across the battlefield in a series of bounding leaps, ignoring injury and tiredness until they have run down their exhausted quarry and torn it apart with frenzied strikes of their scythe-like claws.

units.name: Ravener
units.description: Fast beast unit bred for close combat.
units.flavour: Raveners are voracious predators, their clawed and snake-like bodies driven onwards by an all-consuming hunger. Twisted musculature grants these beasts a terrifying turn of speed. Raveners can bound over small obstacles in an eye-blink, dart between larger obstructions and even slither through flooded marshland with bewildering swiftness. The power housed within the Raveners' wiry forms allows them to burrow long distances beneath a world's surface, before emerging in a spray of earth right in front of an enemy position, claws eviscerating their ambushed prey whilst their thorax-mounted weapon symbiotes spit death.

units.name: Lictor
units.description: Stealth infantry unit.
units.flavour: The Lictor is a highly specialised development of the Tyranid Warrior bioform, specifically adapted to fill a scout role in the vanguard of the Tyranid advance. Lictors rove ahead of the main body of a swarm, seeking out pockets of resistance to be eradicated and native life forms to be absorbed. Able to move swiftly and without sound through even the densest terrain, and concealed by a chameleonic carapace that renders it all but invisible to the naked eye, a Lictor can remain hidden until it chooses to strike. It can wait motionless for days, unnoticed by its victims, an unseen herald of approaching disaster.

units.name: ScythedHierodule
units.description: Agile gargantuan creature unit that shreds entire armies.
units.flavour: The Scythed Hierodule was first recorded during the invasion of Hamman's World, a small Imperial colony close to one of the tendrils of Hive Fleet Kraken. Hamman's World was attacked soon after Kraken's defeat on Ichar IV as the hive fleet began to splinter. Nothing like the Hierodule has ever been reported before. It is armed with four huge razor-sharp claws, each capable of slicing clean through a battle tank, and heavily protected by chitin plates, in places up to 30 cm thick. A Hierodule is far larger than a Carnifex and is a monstrous-killing machine, even by Tyranid standards.

units.name: SporeMine
units.description: Slow unit that detonates itself when coming in contact with an enemy.
units.flavour: Spore Mines have been known to drift for days, just waiting for an unwary foe to come near, before detonating with brutal effect.

units.name: Malanthrope
units.description: Support unit that consumes tiles and founds new cities.
units.flavour: Malanthropes are rarely seen Tyranid creatures. This is because they are not truly warrior organisms, and so are not usually encountered by a prey world's defenders. Instead, these floating creatures follow behind the Tyranid attack; they are typically created only after a prey world's protectors have been defeated and the swarm is in the process of devouring the planet's biomass. On those few occasions that a survivor has seen a Malanthrope and somehow escaped, they have brought with them a tale of horror. They report seeing these giants drift across corpse-strewn battlefields, but unlike other Tyranids, which mindlessly devour everything in their way, Malanthropes seem to selectively search through the slain—as to what they are searching for, none can say.

units.name: Termagant
units.description: Basic infantry unit.
units.flavour: Termagants are agile and cunning creatures. They are amongst the smallest of the Hive Mind's warriors and were originally created to roam the arterial passages of bio-ships in search of intruders. In planetary invasions, Termagants scuttle forwards on four legs whilst unleashing torrents of fire from the anti-personnel bio-weaponry—commonly fleshborers—clutched in their clawed forelimbs.

units.name: Tervigon
units.description: Synapse hero unit that spawns armies of Termagants.
units.flavour: The Tervigon is a massive synapse creature whose towering carapace shields a swollen abdomen. Though possessed of a formidable array of bio-weapons, from monstrous claws that crush any prey that ventures too close, to banks of razor-tipped spines that can be fired a considerable distance, the Tervigon's true threat lies within… Every Tervigon serves as a living incubator, within whose bloated form dozens upon dozens of Termagants slumber in a state of near-life. The Tervigon can spawn its dormant broods at will, jolting their minds into wakefulness.

units.name: Trygon
units.description: Monstrous creature unit that can initiate subterranean assaults.
units.flavour: The Trygon is a vast serpentine creature, so colossal that it towers over even the mighty Carnifex. It is a heavily armoured monster, covered from head to tail with a thick carapace of shifting plates. As the Trygon moves, these plates generate a potent bio-static charge that courses along the length of the beast's body and wreathes its bladed forelimbs with crackling power. The Trygon can direct this energy as a lethal high-voltage discharge—unleashing pulsing arcs of lightning that leave its prey as little more than a charred pile of scorched bones.

units.name: TyranidPrime
units.description: Fearsome synapse hero unit that boosts allied Tyranid Warriors.
units.flavour: Tyranid Primes are the apex of the Tyranid Warrior strain, faster, stronger and smarter than the other Warriors they lead to battle, who instinctively emulate their deadly skill.

units.name: Tunnel
units.description: Allows units to tunnel from one Broodhive to another.
units.flavour: Where the Tyranids arrive, the plants that constitute the Broodhive travel with them. Rapidly proliferating from seeds left by the Tyranid swarm as they pass, these plants burrow their giant hollow roots through soil, metal or stone, enabling Tyranids to pass undetected between areas.

units.name: Tyrannofex
units.description: Monstrous creature unit with long-range weaponry that annihilates even the heaviest vehicles.
units.flavour: There can be little doubt that the massive Tyrannofex exists purely for destruction—it is a monster created for the most apocalyptic and gruelling of battlegrounds. Striding ominously towards their prey, these alien giants deal death from afar, shattering enemy battle lines with merciless salvos of bio-weapons fire. The only way to stop the unrelenting slaughter is to slay the beast, but a Tyrannofex has the fortitude of a living battle fortress and is heedless of all but the heaviest enemy ordnance. Clad in ablative layers of chitinous armour, a Tyrannofex is as unyielding as any war engine built of steel or born of conventional technology.

units.name: Venomthrope
units.description: Infantry unit with poisonous attacks and a protective spore cloud.
units.flavour: The Venomthrope serves as a living chemical weapon dispenser for the swarms of the Tyranid hive fleets. Its whip-like tentacles drip with a multitude of alien poisons. Indeed, so potent are these toxins that it is believed that a Venomthrope's very touch means certain death.

units.name: Warrior
units.description: Versatile synapse infantry unit.
units.flavour: Tyranid Warriors are the most adaptable of all the Hive Mind's bioforms. They are creatures from the blackest of nightmares, unstoppable killing machines with pulsing ichor for blood, needle-sharp teeth and darkly gleaming eyes that reveal a terrible intelligence at work. A Tyranid Warrior stands twice the height of a man, its carapace protected by a thick chitin. One might expect such a creature to be slow in its actions, but a Tyranid Warrior is lithe, with reactions as swift as a whip.

units.name: Zoanthrope
units.description: Synapse infantry unit with devastating psychic capabilities.
units.flavour: Zoanthropes are created solely to harness the psychic potential of the Hive Mind, and their entire bodies are perfected towards such a function. If necessary, a Zoanthrope can be used to extend the range of the Hive Mind's synaptic control, utilising the beast's vast cerebral capacity to relay its instructions to lesser creatures. A Zoanthrope's link to the synaptic web is such that, by flexing the merest part of its mind, it can rain incandescent power on the enemy, projecting destructive bolts of energy that boils through adamantium plate and disintegrates flesh with equal ease.

buildings.name: Biomass
buildings.flavour: A Reclamation Pool is one of the core structures of a Tyranid invasion, a wide bubbling cartilaginous pit bubbling with acids and enzymes. Irrespective of the war raging around it, the Hive's swarming rippers bring collected biomass to the Reclamation Pool where it is dissolved. In a normal situation, it would be fed through Capillary Towers up to the waiting Hive Fleet; on Gladius, the biomass is stored or used in the creation of more troops.

buildings.name: Aircraft
buildings.description: Building that produces flying monstrous creatures and generates research as well as increases the loyalty and population limit.
buildings.flavour: Tall as a human Hive City, Capillary Towers are the backbone of Tyranid conquest. Here, the resources of the planet are siphoned from Reclamation Pools and fed up through the troposphere to meet the umbilical tongues of orbiting Hive ships. On Gladius, the Towers have no Hive Ships to feed. Instead, Gargoyles and Hive Crones crawl from birthing sacs on the Tower's sides and wait for their newborn wings to stiffen so they can join the war.

buildings.name: Construction
buildings.description: Building that constructs new buildings as well as generates biomass and increases the population limit.
buildings.flavour: Nothing reflects the inhumanity of a hive more than the Megafauna Sac. To a human eye, its smooth membranous dome is reminiscent of a design for a museum. However, when it tears itself asunder to reveal another giant biostructure, pulsating and screaming in its birth throes—when that building is half-dragged, half-crawls its towering flesh into position—when the Sac gums itself back together and ripper swarms consume its afterbirth—the human mind then sees it as truly alien.

buildings.name: Headquarters
buildings.flavour: The organising organism of a Tyranid's hive, the Norn Cyst is always the first biostructure to be placed. The Malanthrope places the hive in a suitable location and tends its exponential growth as the hive manages and defends any connected biostructures. When the hive's use has passed, the Malanthrope strips the Cyst's living connections and carries to a new source of biomass. The remaining redundant structure sloughs itself back into the nearest reclamation pool. Soon, the hive is completely gone.

buildings.name: Heroes
buildings.description: Building that produces heroes as well as generates biomass and increases loyalty.
buildings.flavour: Whilst the Anthropia emerge solely from the Aedanthropum's long-gestation sacs, the most complex synapse creatures take even more of the Hive Mind's resources and, crucially, focus. Each Tyrant, Tervigon and Prime requires careful design from the Mind, to give it that balance between total control and useful independence. The concentrated sensoria of the Ovipository enable that focus.

buildings.name: Housing
buildings.flavour: Excess biomass and genetic data are simply stored in the thickened walls of the biostructures or flow twitching between them. But when a creature has been grown, sometimes the Hive Mind deems it more efficient to retain it but shut down its functions, stored in serried ranks of marsupia.

buildings.name: Influence
buildings.flavour: The Hive Mind's capabilities aren't spread evenly throughout its structures—somewhere, there needs to be concentrated systems for thought. In the Hive Fleet, these are the Norn Queens. On the ground, these synapses act as temporary back-ups to the network effect from its individual creatures, allowing the Mind to focus on more objectives than simply controlling the swarm.

buildings.name: Infantry
buildings.description: Building that produces infantry and beasts as well as generates biomass.
buildings.flavour: While a Norn Queen normally produces all the creatures of a Tyranid invasion, in the circumstances that a brood is physically isolated from the Hive Fleet, certain specialised structures are used. Smaller creatures like Termagants are gestated in the pods of this nest, fed and warmed by the unthinking structures.

buildings.name: Loyalty
buildings.flavour: An Imperial scholar, might make an analogy between a coherence node and something like a radio tower—and, certainly, it's orchid-ear appearance fits—but it doesn't transmit but receives. The node's folded surfaces track the locations of the Hive Mind's creatures for the most efficient deployment of its synapses, to prevent the Hive swarms falling into anarchy and chaos.

buildings.name: Research
buildings.flavour: Though the Malanthropes are responsible for physically collecting genetic data from a planet's population, the Epicure is the structure that processes those samples. Inside the Epicure's fluted mass, delicate structures pare and sort the genetic samples, testing them on a microscopic scale for useful innovations. When something is discovered, it is immediately communicated to the Norn Cyst and hence onto the Hive Mind.

buildings.name: Vehicles
buildings.description: Building that produces ground-based monstrous creatures and generates biomass.
buildings.flavour: Some of the Hive Mind's creations are produced by separate biostructures because of the care and resources taken in their rendering. Others are simply large. The Brood Haunt houses those brutish giants that are far too big for the Brood Nest. Inside this high-spined haunt, womb-caverns of bone filled with suspensory fluid allow the layering of muscle and bone for these monstrous giants.

buildings.name: Thropes
buildings.description: Building that produces Thropes and generates research.
buildings.flavour: Not all Tyranid creatures are equal; whilst Termagants and Hormagaunts require little focus and unspecialised resources, the construction and gestation of more complex creatures can take more care. In isolated hives like that of Gladius, the diverse support creatures the Imperium calls Anthropia—Venomthropes, Zoanthropes and Malanthropes—all emerge from a specialised biostructure of gristly columns, podia and caverns.

upgrades.name: AdrenalGlands
upgrades.description: Grants units increased movement and increased melee damage.
upgrades.flavour: Adrenal glands saturate their host's bodies with chemicals that boost the creature's metabolism to a hyperactive state of frenzy.

upgrades.name: AcidBlood
upgrades.description: Grants Tyranid monstrous creatures and Tyranid Primes the trait to damage all melee attackers.
upgrades.flavour: The alien blood spilt from certain Tyranids is so corrosive that it can eat through ceramite armour and dissolve flesh in mere moments.

upgrades.name: Aircraft
upgrades.description: Building that produces flying monstrous creatures and generates research as well as increases the loyalty and population limit.
upgrades.flavour: Tall as a human Hive City, Capillary Towers are the backbone of Tyranid conquest. Here, the resources of the planet are siphoned from Reclamation Pools and fed up through the troposphere to meet the umbilical tongues of orbiting Hive ships. On Gladius, the Towers have no Hive Ships to feed. Instead, Gargoyles and Hive Crones crawl from birthing sacs on the Tower's sides and wait for their newborn wings to stiffen so they can join the war.

upgrades.name: BiomorphDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of biomorphs.
upgrades.flavour: Far from being born perfectly ready for every situation, Tyranids have variable amounts of adaptability inherent in their DNA. Ramping this capability up is expensive in terms of resources, but allows them to change their behaviour and physical capabilities in the field.

upgrades.name: BioPlasma
upgrades.description: Grants Carnifexes an additional ranged weapon.
upgrades.flavour: Some Carnifexes can generate a roaring ball of bio-plasma within their bodies and vomit forth the resultant energy as an incandescent gobbet of fire.

upgrades.name: Biovore
upgrades.description: Artillery unit that creates Spore Mines which explode on contact with the enemy.
upgrades.flavour: A Biovore is a squat, bloated creature—yet no less deadly for all that. Deep within its lumpen form, the Biovore nurtures a clutch of Spore Mines—living bombs that blanket the enemy in acids, poisons and shrapnel-sized pieces of chitin. Biovores thump forward in battle, bony protrusions on their fore-limbs anchoring themselves into the ground as they release their vile payload in a single shuddering spasm.

upgrades.name: BoneMace
upgrades.description: Grants Carnifexes an additional melee weapon.
upgrades.flavour: The tails of some Tyranids are deadly weapons, from bony protrusions dense enough to cave in the side of a tank to stingers containing enough poison to kill whole regiments.

upgrades.name: CityDamage
upgrades.description: Enemy units in Tyranid cities take damage each turn.
upgrades.flavour: To enter into a mature Tyranid city, is to walk inside giants—hostile, biologically-crafted giants, determined to consume you. Toxin-coated villi lash infantry, valleys sprout teeth and close like maws, and town square-sized sphincters open suddenly, dumping entire unwary armies into acidic reclamation pools.

upgrades.name: CityLoyalty
upgrades.description: Decreases the loyalty penalty from the amount of Tyranid cities.
upgrades.flavour: Throughout the hive, from the great producer organisms, to the smaller maintenance creatures, to the substrate itself, small packages of grey matter are dispersed, increasing the ease with which swarm creatures can be controlled.

upgrades.name: CityGrowth
upgrades.description: Increases the growth rate of Tyranid cities.
upgrades.flavour: Tyranid cities place little value on size, but focus instead on productivity. As long as a city is efficiently churning out troops, it doesn't matter if it occupies land. But when a city must expand, it can do it extremely rapidly—from sphincters fly hooked tendons, dragging seed pods out to the landscape, where they erupt like Barbed Stranglers. In moments the land is occupied, rapidly gestating a new structure.

upgrades.name: CityCost
upgrades.description: Reduces the cost of founding new cities.
upgrades.flavour: The role of the Malanthrope in founding new Tyranid hives has been little studied by Imperial Genetors, as in most circumstances they're dead or fleeing when the hive is founded. However, it's believed that they transport the city seed to new locations when a forward brood location is required. Unusual Malanthropes have sometimes been observed, with specialised physical structures that enable them to perform this task more efficiently.

upgrades.name: CityPopulationLimit
upgrades.description: Increases the population limit of Tyranid cities.
upgrades.flavour: Nothing truly “lives” in a Tyranid city-hive. Mindless 'organelle' creatures spawn and perform crucial functions before being reassimilated. Alterations to the city structure can be made, enabling these organisms to be spawned and reabsorbed in much shorter windows, allowing for their overall population to increase.

upgrades.name: CityProduction
upgrades.description: Increases the production output of Tyranid cities.
upgrades.flavour: Waiting for Tyranid newborns to leave their respective mother-buildings is relatively inefficient. Genetors have sighted certain adapted buildings, however, which eject the newborn creature from its birthing sac with an convulsive electric impulse, enabling it to be rapidly re-used.

upgrades.name: CityTier2
upgrades.description: Increases the tile acquisition radius of the city.
upgrades.flavour: As the hive matures, the Rippers no longer need to swarm together in such huge numbers for safety. Dispersing them, allows the hive mind to co-ordinate their reclamation behaviour over a wider range.

upgrades.name: Construction
upgrades.description: Building that constructs new buildings as well as generates biomass and increases the population limit.
upgrades.flavour: Nothing reflects the inhumanity of a hive more than the Megafauna Sac. To a human eye, its smooth membranous dome is reminiscent of a design for a museum. However, when it tears itself asunder to reveal another giant biostructure, pulsating and screaming in its birth throes—when that building is half-dragged, half-crawls its towering flesh into position—when the Sac gums itself back together and ripper swarms consume its afterbirth—the human mind then sees it as truly alien.

upgrades.name: ConsumeTile2
upgrades.description: Decreases the influence cost of consuming tiles.
upgrades.flavour: Whilst a Malanthrope or Ripper's razor-edged jaws have no problem eating their way through flesh, bone or even plasteel, they are slowed by the necessity of consuming the huge quantities of soil and rock the Hive Mind demands at scale and speed. It is presumed that specialised organisms are deployed to consume these—though, again, none have survived to report them.

upgrades.name: Deathspitter
upgrades.description: Grants Raveners a ranged weapon.
upgrades.flavour: This multi-creature symbiote fires maggot-like organisms with corrosive innards. A spider-jawed set of fangs drags an organism from the weapon's brooding chamber and strips off its shell, before the deathspitter reacts to the caustic flesh with a spasm, firing the maggot to explode in a shower of caustic slime against its target.

upgrades.name: DesiccatorLarvae
upgrades.description: Grants Hive Tyrants, Tervigons and Tyrannofexes a template weapon.
upgrades.flavour: Certain Tyranids have thoracic cavities that play host to swarms of parasites—some of these minute creatures drain their victims' vital fluids, others emit an electrical charge which plays havoc with enemy vehicles, and others still nestle amongst the foe's armour before exploding in a horrific fashion.

upgrades.name: Exocrine
upgrades.description: Monstrous creature unit that excels when stationary.
upgrades.flavour: Exocrines are feared for their ability to deal death from afar. The most distinctive feature of an Exocrine is its dorsal bio-cannon, which emits a high-pitched hiss a second before firing, giving its prey just enough time to realise the danger they are in before searing plasma scours them into atoms.

upgrades.name: ExtraInfantryArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of infantry.
upgrades.flavour: The Hive Mind is a frugal mentality. Why sacrifice resources armouring troops that will be reclaimed anyway? Only when the gamble makes sense, does it invest in extra-thick chitin and bone for its fauna.

upgrades.name: ExtraMonstrousCreatureArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of monstrous creatures.
upgrades.flavour: Through a combination of hardened carapaces, disruptive fields and deadened nerve endings, the Hive Mind can alter the resilience of its larger creatures easily.

upgrades.name: FleshHooks
upgrades.description: Grants Tyranid Warriors, Tyranid Primes and Lictors an additional ranged weapon.
upgrades.flavour: Flesh hooks are attached to a Tyranid's ribcage by ropy tendrils and allow it to scale sheer surfaces or snare prey at close range.

upgrades.name: HammerOfWrath
upgrades.description: Grants Exocrines, Gargoyles, Haruspexes, Hive Crones, Hive Tyrants, Scythed Hierodules, Tervigons, Trygons and Tyrannofexes the ability to perform more devastating attacks.
upgrades.flavour: Many warriors hurl themselves headlong into combat, seeking to crush or trample the foe.

upgrades.name: Haruspex
upgrades.description: Monstrous creature unit with a grasping tongue.
upgrades.flavour: The Tyranid Haruspex is a ferocious beast created to consume biomass at a sickening pace. It is possessed of a rapacious appetite, driven by the need to sate an infinite hunger. Few foes are foolish enough to stand before a feeding Haruspex, for it can devour an entire platoon of soldiers in a matter of moments, shovelling victim after victim into its craw without ever slowing down. Any morsel that proves too large to be swallowed in one gulp is seized with the Haruspex's gargantuan claws and ripped, crushed or battered apart with negligent ease.

upgrades.name: Heroes
upgrades.description: Building that produces heroes as well as generates biomass and increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: Whilst the Anthropia emerge solely from the Aedanthropum's long-gestation sacs, the most complex synapse creatures take even more of the Hive Mind's resources and, crucially, focus. Each Tyrant, Tervigon and Prime requires careful design from the Mind, to give it that balance between total control and useful independence. The concentrated sensoria of the Ovipository enable that focus.

upgrades.name: Gargoyle
upgrades.description: Jump infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: A Tyranid attack is preceded by the beating of thousands of membranous wings as Gargoyle broods descend upon the foe, blotting out the sun and spitting death from their fleshborers. Their winged manoeuvrability gives Gargoyles a distinct hunting advantage. Wherever Tyranids attack a planet, the defenders look fearfully to the skies, for they know that every sky-borne shadow could be a flock of Gargoyles about to attack.

upgrades.name: HiveTyrant
upgrades.description: Flying synapse hero unit with terrifying psychic powers.
upgrades.flavour: Hive Tyrants are the commanders of the Tyranid swarms and enact the Hive Mind's will on the field of battle. Though individuals display a wide variety of physical characteristics, all Hive Tyrants are fearsome hulking monsters that tower over even a Dreadnought. They are brutally strong, able to shatter ferrocrete with sickening ease. Every part of such a beast's body is perfectly created to kill, even the layers of chitinous plating that protect them. A Hive Tyrant is a formidable opponent at any distance, as deadly with ranged weapons as it is with bonesword or claw.

upgrades.name: Hormagaunt
upgrades.description: Basic close combat infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: Hormagaunts are vicious and extraordinarily single-minded predators that will pursue their victims without pause or respite. With powerful hind legs, Hormagaunts dart across the battlefield in a series of bounding leaps, ignoring injury and tiredness until they have run down their exhausted quarry and torn it apart with frenzied strikes of their scythe-like claws.

upgrades.name: Housing
upgrades.description: Building that increases population limit.
upgrades.flavour: Excess biomass and genetic data are simply stored in the thickened walls of the biostructures or flow twitching between them. But when a creature has been grown, sometimes the Hive Mind deems it more efficient to retain it but shut down its functions, stored in serried ranks of marsupia.

upgrades.name: InfantryUpkeep
upgrades.description: Reduces the biomass upkeep of infantry.
upgrades.flavour: The Hive Mind typically maintains close control over its swarm, directing everything save for unconscious actions—but by loosening that control, the smaller organisms can be allowed just enough agency to forage for themselves.

upgrades.name: InstinctiveBehaviourOverride2
upgrades.description: Reduces the influence cost of overriding instinctive behaviour.
upgrades.flavour: Maintaining control of its troops is a major concern of the hive mind and one it seeks to overcome by various adaptations, such as its synapse creatures. A simpler one is to reduce the natural savagery of its units when they run feral, so they require less psychic effort to bring back under control.

upgrades.name: Loyalty
upgrades.description: Building that increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: An Imperial scholar, might make an analogy between a coherence node and something like a radio tower—and, certainly, it's orchid-ear appearance fits—but it doesn't transmit but receives. The node's folded surfaces track the locations of the Hive Mind's creatures for the most efficient deployment of its synapses, to prevent the Hive swarms falling into anarchy and chaos.

upgrades.name: Lictor
upgrades.description: Stealth infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: The Lictor is a highly specialised development of the Tyranid Warrior bioform, specifically adapted to fill a scout role in the vanguard of the Tyranid advance. Lictors rove ahead of the main body of a swarm, seeking out pockets of resistance to be eradicated and native life forms to be absorbed. Able to move swiftly and without sound through even the densest terrain, and concealed by a chameleonic carapace that renders it all but invisible to the naked eye, a Lictor can remain hidden until it chooses to strike. It can wait motionless for days, unnoticed by its victims, an unseen herald of approaching disaster.

upgrades.name: LongRangedDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of long-ranged weapons.
upgrades.flavour: Targeting enemies at range can be difficult with simple binocular vision. A sensible adaptation is to increase the variety and number of ocular sensors available to the organism, to improve the targeting of all enemy types.

upgrades.name: MeleeDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of melee weapons.
upgrades.flavour: When the Tyranids were first encountered, particularly their forerunners the Zoats, their weaponry was typically a range of separate organisms. As time has gone by, the Tyranids and their weapons have grown closer together.

upgrades.name: Paroxysm
upgrades.description: Grants Zoanthropes the ability to curse enemy units so they have decreased accuracy.
upgrades.flavour: The Hive Mind debilitates its enemies by triggering every nerve and pain receptor in their bodies, overwhelming their senses with wracking fits of agony.

upgrades.name: PreyAdaptation2
upgrades.description: Increases the research gained when enemies die in the area of a Malanthrope.
upgrades.flavour: An unusual adaptation of the Malanthropic form, gustarflagelli are filament thin tendrils that surround a malanthrope like a fleshy, wriggling cloud. It's presumed that they enable the Malanthrope to gather and retain more genetic data from recently-deceased enemies.

upgrades.name: ProductionBuildingUpkeep
upgrades.description: Reduces the influence upkeep of production buildings.
upgrades.flavour: A simple shift in the structure of the great organisms that make up the Tyranid hive, birthing canals are something like biological production lines, enabling many creatures to be produced in parallel without the direct oversight of the Hive Mind.

upgrades.name: Reclamation2
upgrades.description: Reduces the influence cost of reclamation.
upgrades.flavour: Reclamation pools may seem the simplest of Tyranid organisms—bubbling digestive pits to render down biomass—but given their core function to the Tyranid lifecycle, they have doubtless seen generations of design refinement. This particular adaptation places control synapses at each pool's edge to manage digestion with less Hive Mind oversight.

upgrades.name: Reclamation3
upgrades.description: Removes the cooldown of reclamation.
upgrades.flavour: Reclamation has to be an efficient process to best serve the Hive Mind—every basis point of biomass that has to be abandoned could spell defeat. This adaptation makes reclamation a continuous process, which enables high percentage biomass recovery.

upgrades.name: Ravener
upgrades.description: Fast beast unit bred for close combat.
upgrades.flavour: Raveners are voracious predators, their clawed and snake-like bodies driven onwards by an all-consuming hunger. Twisted musculature grants these beasts a terrifying turn of speed. Raveners can bound over small obstacles in an eye-blink, dart between larger obstructions and even slither through flooded marshland with bewildering swiftness. The power housed within the Raveners' wiry forms allows them to burrow long distances beneath a world's surface, before emerging in a spray of earth right in front of an enemy position, claws eviscerating their ambushed prey whilst their thorax-mounted weapon symbiotes spit death.

upgrades.name: Regeneration
upgrades.description: Grants Tyranid monstrous creatures and Tyranid Primes hitpoint restoration each turn.
upgrades.flavour: Some units have the ability to recover from horrendous wounds and injuries that should have proven fatal.

upgrades.name: ResourceBuildingUpkeep
upgrades.description: Reduces the influence upkeep of resource buildings.
upgrades.flavour: The Hive Mind typically maintains close control over its swarm, directing everything but unconscious actions—but by loosening that control, the smaller organisms can be allowed just enough agency to forage for themselves.

upgrades.name: ShortRangedDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of short-ranged weapons.
upgrades.flavour: The unique and disgusting Borer nest is comprised of a compact nest of Borer beetles, acidic insectoids that launch themselves in a frenzy from the weapon. Gigaborer Hives contain fewer, much larger beetles, simply enabling more damage.

upgrades.name: StingerSalvo
upgrades.description: Grants Hive Crones an additional ranged weapon.
upgrades.flavour: Stinger salvoes are simple but effective weapons that fire rows of metre-long, razor-sharp spikes.

upgrades.name: Tervigon
upgrades.description: Synapse hero unit that spawns armies of Termagants.
upgrades.flavour: The Tervigon is a massive synapse creature whose towering carapace shields a swollen abdomen. Though possessed of a formidable array of bio-weapons, from monstrous claws that crush any prey that ventures too close, to banks of razor-tipped spines that can be fired a considerable distance, the Tervigon's true threat lies within… Every Tervigon serves as a living incubator, within whose bloated form dozens upon dozens of Termagants slumber in a state of near-life. The Tervigon can spawn its dormant broods at will, jolting their minds into wakefulness.

upgrades.name: ScythedHierodule
upgrades.description: Agile gargantuan creature unit that shreds entire armies.
upgrades.flavour: The Scythed Hierodule was first recorded during the invasion of Hamman's World, a small Imperial colony close to one of the tendrils of Hive Fleet Kraken. Hamman's World was attacked soon after Kraken's defeat on Ichar IV as the hive fleet began to splinter. Nothing like the Hierodule has ever been reported before. It is armed with four huge razor-sharp claws, each capable of slicing clean through a battle tank, and heavily protected by chitin plates, in places up to 30 cm thick. A Hierodule is far larger than a Carnifex and is a monstrous-killing machine, even by Tyranid standards.

upgrades.name: Toxinspike
upgrades.description: Grants Trygons an additional melee weapon.
upgrades.flavour: The tails of some Tyranids are deadly weapons, from bony protrusions dense enough to cave in the side of a tank to stingers containing enough poison to kill whole regiments.

upgrades.name: ThresherScythe
upgrades.description: Grants Exocrines and Haruspexes an additional melee weapon.
upgrades.flavour: The tails of some Tyranids are deadly weapons, from bony protrusions dense enough to cave in the side of a tank to stingers containing enough poison to kill whole regiments.

upgrades.name: Thropes
upgrades.description: Building that produces Thropes and generates research.
upgrades.flavour: Not all Tyranid creatures are equal; whilst Termagants and Hormagaunts require little focus and unspecialised resources, the construction and gestation of more complex creatures can take more care. In isolated hives like that of Gladius, the diverse support creatures the Imperium calls Anthropia—Venomthropes, Zoanthropes and Malanthropes—all emerge from a specialised biostructure of gristly columns, podia and caverns.

upgrades.name: Trygon
upgrades.description: Monstrous creature unit that can initiate subterranean assaults.
upgrades.flavour: The Trygon is a vast serpentine creature, so colossal that it towers over even the mighty Carnifex. It is a heavily armoured monster, covered from head to tail with a thick carapace of shifting plates. As the Trygon moves, these plates generate a potent bio-static charge that courses along the length of the beast's body and wreathes its bladed forelimbs with crackling power. The Trygon can direct this energy as a lethal high-voltage discharge—unleashing pulsing arcs of lightning that leave its prey as little more than a charred pile of scorched bones.

upgrades.name: Tunnel2
upgrades.description: Increases the hitpoints of Broodhives.
upgrades.flavour: Broodhive walls are grown rapidly, meaning they tend to be relatively flimsy creatures, for the Tyranids. Genetors have observed adaptations that grow more slowly, but accrete muscle mass over time, and generally are more resilient to enemy action.

upgrades.name: ToxinSacs
upgrades.description: Increases the damage of melee weapons against infantry and monstrous creatures.
upgrades.flavour: These parasitic glands secrete vile fluids, coating the Tyranid's claws, fangs and talons with a lethal variety of alien poisons.

upgrades.name: Tyrannofex
upgrades.description: Monstrous creature unit with long-range weaponry that annihilates even the heaviest vehicles.
upgrades.flavour: There can be little doubt that the massive Tyrannofex exists purely for destruction—it is a monster created for the most apocalyptic and gruelling of battlegrounds. Striding ominously towards their prey, these alien giants deal death from afar, shattering enemy battle lines with merciless salvos of bio-weapons fire. The only way to stop the unrelenting slaughter is to slay the beast, but a Tyrannofex has the fortitude of a living battle fortress and is heedless of all but the heaviest enemy ordnance. Clad in ablative layers of chitinous armour, a Tyrannofex is as unyielding as any war engine built of steel or born of conventional technology.

upgrades.name: Vehicles
upgrades.description: Building that produces ground-based monstrous creatures and generates biomass.
upgrades.flavour: Some of the Hive Mind's creations are produced by separate biostructures because of the care and resources taken in their rendering. Others are simply large. The Brood Haunt houses those brutish giants that are far too big for the Brood Nest. Inside this high-spined haunt, womb-caverns of bone filled with suspensory fluid allow the layering of muscle and bone for these monstrous giants.

upgrades.name: VehiclesUpkeep
upgrades.description: Reduces the biomass upkeep of monstrous creatures.
upgrades.flavour: The Hive Mind typically maintains close control over its swarm, directing everything but unconscious actions, save for its alpha creatures—but by loosening that control, larger organisms can direct or predate on the smaller organisms, enabling them to survive without direct control.

upgrades.name: Warrior
upgrades.description: Versatile synapse infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: Tyranid Warriors are the most adaptable of all the Hive Mind's bioforms. They are creatures from the blackest of nightmares, unstoppable killing machines with pulsing ichor for blood, needle-sharp teeth and darkly gleaming eyes that reveal a terrible intelligence at work. A Tyranid Warrior stands twice the height of a man, its carapace protected by a thick chitin. One might expect such a creature to be slow in its actions, but a Tyranid Warrior is lithe, with reactions as swift as a whip.

upgrades.name: Venomthrope
upgrades.description: Infantry unit with poisonous attacks and a protective spore cloud.
upgrades.flavour: The Venomthrope serves as a living chemical weapon dispenser for the swarms of the Tyranid hive fleets. Its whip-like tentacles drip with a multitude of alien poisons. Indeed, so potent are these toxins that it is believed that a Venomthrope's very touch means certain death.

upgrades.name: Zoanthrope
upgrades.description: Synapse infantry unit with devastating psychic capabilities.
upgrades.flavour: Zoanthropes are created solely to harness the psychic potential of the Hive Mind, and their entire bodies are perfected towards such a function. If necessary, a Zoanthrope can be used to extend the range of the Hive Mind's synaptic control, utilising the beast's vast cerebral capacity to relay its instructions to lesser creatures. A Zoanthrope's link to the synaptic web is such that, by flexing the merest part of its mind, it can rain incandescent power on the enemy, projecting destructive bolts of energy that boils through adamantium plate and disintegrates flesh with equal ease.
